awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Geometric Techniques for Algorithm Design
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new mathematical techniques for algorithm design, and it applied them to advance the state-of-the-art in a wide range of settings.  

A primary focus of the project was graph algorithms.  Graph theory has become a fundamental tool throughout the physical, biological, and social sciences.  In recent years, it has become increasingly common for the graphs being studied to be so huge that even quadratic-time algorithms are too slow to consider running on these graphs.  This motivates the development of algorithms whose running times are as close to linear as possible.

The work in this project aimed to develop a new collection of tools for this endeavor by exploiting the algebraic properties of various operators associated with graphs, using these to augment classical combinatorial approaches with ideas rooted in continuous optimization, geometry, and numerical linear algebra.  This led to several substantial algorithmic advances, including:

  • A new mathematical framework for graph algorithms that led to faster algorithms for several of the most extensively-studied and widely-applied tasks in algorithmic graph theory, in some cases breaking barriers for fundamental problems that had stood for decades.
  • Improved methods for routing data and disseminating information in computer networks, as well as for deducing the structure of such networks from very limited measurements.
  • A new approach to solving ubiquitous classes of linear systems, leading to nearly-linear-time algorithms for many computational linear algebra problems that appear frequently in scientific computing and data analysis.
  • Better methods for efficiently approximating the solutions of problems that are too difficult to solve exactly.
  • Applications of the mathematical techniques developed for this work to other fields, including computational biology, quantum information theory, and machine learning.

The work produced by the project received Best Paper awards at several of the top venues in the field, and it funded students whose work also received multiple Best Paper and Best Student Paper awards at these venues.  Students trained under this project have gone on to obtain tenure-track jobs at top universities, including MIT, Carnegie Mellon, and Stanford.
